channel.title: How silly
channel.description:
Right now I'm on my sister's laptop. I'm using the default "Administrator" account (via safe-boot with networking). She has a password-protected account of her own and thought I hacked into her account.
ITT: Silly people. Share stories of silliness!

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:25, topic:376861”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=472781.msg3462436#msg3462436 date=1294586803]
if I was going to encrypt everything, I’d want it to be a uniform kind of encryption, rather than using LUKS on Linux and TrueCrypt on Windows.
[/quote]

I’ve never tried it, but I’m pretty sure the TrueCrypt loader can be coaxed into booting Linux.[/quote]

It says it’s compatible with Windows/Mac/Linux and even encrypting the entire drive with multiple OSes as long as it uses it’s own bootloader outside of the encryption.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

SomethingToHide:

if I was going to encrypt everything, I’d want it to be a uniform kind of encryption, rather than using LUKS on Linux and TrueCrypt on Windows.

I’ve never tried it, but I’m pretty sure the TrueCrypt loader can be coaxed into booting Linux.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:23, topic:376861”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=472781.msg3462301#msg3462301 date=1294571666]
Would you guys use LUKS (or any other Linux encryption or file system) on windows if you could? (not for the root filesystem, but for anything else) I’m curious because over a year ago I wrote some code that allows this, and this thread reminded me I should finish and get it out there. The question is, would you use it?
[/quote]

Or file system? What do you mean? I haven’t looked into LUKS much, but if I was going to encrypt everything, I’d want it to be a uniform kind of encryption, rather than using LUKS on Linux and TrueCrypt on Windows.[/quote]

LUKS encrypts block devices on linux, which means you can run the filesystem of your choice over top of it (like ext4, for example). What I am talking about would allow you to use your Linux partitions from windows exactly the same way you use them on linux, including any encryption, filesystems, etc. The one hiccup is that you couldn’t encrypt your root windows partition.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Would you guys use LUKS (or any other Linux encryption or file system) on windows if you could? (not for the root filesystem, but for anything else) I’m curious because over a year ago I wrote some code that allows this, and this thread reminded me I should finish and get it out there. The question is, would you use it?

Or file system? What do you mean? I haven’t looked into LUKS much, but if I was going to encrypt everything, I’d want it to be a uniform kind of encryption, rather than using LUKS on Linux and TrueCrypt on Windows.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:19, topic:376861”]Why not touching TrueCrypt?

Free, always free, open source, plenty of people to go over the code. I haven’t noticed anything wrong with it in my research over the past day or two.

I don’t think I’m going to use it (or any) but I’m really interested now.[/quote]

They don’t consider the license free, because it contains a clause that lets TrueCrypt revoke it or some shit, I forget the details.

Doesn’t bother me, I think it’s great, wouldnt own a laptop without it (unless it was linux i guess)

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Why not touching TrueCrypt?

Free, always free, open source, plenty of people to go over the code. I haven’t noticed anything wrong with it in my research over the past day or two.

I don’t think I’m going to use it (or any) but I’m really interested now.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That’s another issue, do you want to trust the quality of the encryption to some company that is in it for the money (and therefore likely to backdoor their products for the FBI etc), or would you rather have the source reviewed by millions of people and be able to compile it yourself?

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I’ve never used it for a dualboot system, but I imagine their bootloader would just chainload grub (or whatever you use) after decryption.

I disagree about performance not being an issue - if you’re encrypting your whole disk, it’s important that read/writes don’t slow to a crawl surely. Luckily, Truecrypt is fucking amazing in that regard imo, I don’t notice a performance hit at all, even on dog slow machines with laptop HD’s.

There are freedom issues if you’re worried about that kind of thing - the FSF recommend not touching Truecrypt with a bargepole.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Not performs like, performance wise, that was a bad choice of words. I’m saying it has a full drive encryption mode and needs to write it’s own bootloader, and in the newer versions apparently supports all platforms, but I’m not sure how well it works together for a full drive encryption in my example.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you really think you need encryption, then performance shouldn’t even be one of your considerations. Things like the grade of encryption, plausible deniability (can it be identified as an encrypted drive/partition/file? if so, a judge can and will order you to supply the password, plausible deniability means you can say it’s simply an unformatted hard drive, because it looks the same as random data), and similar are what matters.

Read full topic

item.title: How silly
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:376861”][quote author=SomethingToHide link=topic=472781.msg3458821#msg3458821 date=1294281992]
Like TrueCrypt?
Or any better solutions?
[/quote]

LUKS under Linux is how I would do it. :)[/quote]

Looking for a cross platform solution. Dual booting Windows/Linux on all computers currently. Some people have said TrueCrypt for Windows partition and LUKS for Linux partition, but that was a while ago, before TrueCrypt offered something for every platform. I’m not sure how TrueCrypt currently performs with Dual Booting off a single HD and encrypting the entire HD.

Read full topic

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:8, topic:376861”]I was just thinking about this the other day, because anyone who had access to your computer could boot via a live cd and view all your shit anyway.

Although I guess you could disable booting from CD/USB in BIOS and password protect the BIOS.[/quote]But then you could just reset BIOS. Really the only option if you don’t want people to steal your things is if you encrypt.
